original_title: NASA’s Tech Demo Streams First Video From Deep Space via Laser
original_content:
Everyone knows that the most important part of a tech demo is to make the right impression, and the team over at NASAs Jet Propulsion Laboratory (JPL) definitely had this part nailed down when they showed off streaming a cat video from deep space using laser technology as part of NASAs Deep Space Optical Communication (DSOC) program. This system consists out of a ground-based laser transmitter and receiver along with a space-based laser transceiver, which for this experiment was positioned at a distance of 31 million kilometers  80 times the distance between the Moon and Earth  as a part of the Psyche spacecraft.
After a range of tests with the system to shake out potential issues, the team found that they could establish a 267 Mbps link, with a one-way latency of a mere 101 seconds, allowing Psyches transceiver to transmit the preinstalled 15-second high-definition video in effectively real-time and making the cat Taters instantly world-famous. Although the potential for space-based cat videos cannot be underestimated, the main purpose of DSOC is to allow spacecraft to send back much larger data sets than they could before.
For robotic and potential future manned missions DSOC would mean high bandwidth video and data links, enabling more science, better communication and possibly the occasional cat video during interplanetary travel.
title: NASAのディープスペース・オプティカル・コミュニケーションプログラムによる実験で、31億キロの距離からハイビジョンの猫動画をリアルタイムで転送成功
body: NASA JPLが宇宙から猫の動画をストリーミングする実験に成功。267 Mbpsのリンク速度で、距離は31百万キロ。宇宙船の通信手段として期待される。
titles: NASAのディープスペース・オプティカル・コミュニケーションプログラムによる実験で、31億キロの距離からハイビジョンの猫動画をリアルタイムで転送成功
地球と月の距離の80倍にあたる31億キロの距離から猫動画のストリーミングが可能に
ディープスペース・オプティカル・コミュニケーション技術により、宇宙船の大量データ転送が可能に
猫動画の転送実験に成功 - 高帯域幅の宇宙通信技術の将来性に期待
NASAが宇宙船と地球間でリアルタイムのビデオ通信を実現
